history.content:
CS 160 is a generally very popular class and fills up fast. I don't anticipate the standard 10% rule to apply here, given it is not listed in the Schedule of Classes so many people will want to jump on this to do this class.

Physics in general is tough. Alongside an internship is probably even tougher.

Additionally, I don't know about your programming style, but I wrote some preparation advice and expected experience I typed in @14730. I too have taken Hilfinger, so if you were at least able to design your program for his projects, that experience can be brought to CS 160. If not, I would allocate more time for that.

Though they are more concerned about the front end than the back end. However, a good front end doesn't work with a bad back end. Clean code just makes your life easier.

The following next advice comes from the Fall 2020 iteration of CS 160

We had 2 individual programming assignments with all the requirements listed out, relatively smaller in scale than the final group project.

As a scale of my experience, I finished Hilfinger's projects pretty fast and accurately. As a result in CS 160, it would take me 1 to 2 full days of design work and programming, including prepping the deliverables for the project (video recording and a mini-report on design choices and description of the project) on a grind.

The 1 Final Project depends on how skilled your group is and how far they want to take the class. I'm fortunate enough to have an awesome group, but I know some people who aren't as fortunate. I would be mentally prepared for this.

Fall 2020 iteration had group sizes of 4 to 5 of various backgrounds based on a survey.

Time spent on the final project equated to 2 weeks grind each person on a high bound.

You will also have reading and video discussions you will have to do, where you just answer questions about what you read and watched. We had group posts, where we had to arrange some time to meet up on Zoom and compile a response. This can take a good half day on a grind each.

Hi everyone, 

Since it seems like 160 won't be offered in the next school year (and I really want to take this for my design requirement, since I want to learn HCI, and cannot afford to wait another year because I am a rising senior), I was thinking of taking it over the summer. I am in position 40, does the 10% rule apply for summer as well? Or how likely is it for 160 to expand beyond the current 120 seats? (What was the final class size in previous summers?) 
Also, how doable does 160 + Internship + another 1-month CC physics class at Community college sound? I am more worried about what the daily workload for 160 is over the summer, and how often projects/work is due. For anyone that took it before, how many hours did u spend on it per day? How many projects total/how many solo/how many group/what size groups?

I have looked at the Summer 2019 website, but maybe a lot of the material was removed and I couldn't actually see the other lecture slides, only the project docs and the readings (about 20 pages each ish, which I could prob do if I read it here and there on spare 5 minutes intervals). 

For background on programming I have taken CS61A, B (Hilfinger version, if that helps to compare the project workloads?), C, Data C100. Am taking 170, 188. Any insight helps, and thanks in advance!
history.subject: CS 160 over summer + Internship + Another class at CC (3 week overlap with 160)? Waitlist chances?
